instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3534: What is 820-3534? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3534</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Power Issues
threads.message:
I got this board in because it was SOMETIMES turning on, and sometimes not. The device was reaching S0 state, but still not turning on sometimes.

I found almost no liquid damage, apart from two tiny spots. One spot had discoloured a capacitor (<CAPACITOR>C3282</CAPACITOR>), which i replaced even though it wasn't shorted or out of cap. The other spot had ruined a resistor (<RESISTOR>R8178</RESISTOR>), and destroyed the trace beneath. This resistor was a 100ohm, and it carried <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>, which was getting stuck at one end of the dead resistor. I replaced this resistor and repaired the trace and the problem was totally solved. Computer has been perfect for the past two days.

Today, i came to it and it was totally dead again, won't turn on ever now. It seems to be a new problem because more rails are missing. <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> doesn't even exist anymore for example.

I've given the board two thorough cleans through the crest, and i cannot find any other areas of corrosion. Please help!

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.57v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.42v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5.12v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> =5.12v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = 3.32v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> =3.32v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> = 3.32v

[B]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> = 0.05v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 0.00v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> =0.00v[/B]

Any support would be greatly appreciated.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3534</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Power Issues
threads.message: <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> would be a good suspect, pin 8 tends to corrode under the chip. Also <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> area. PPVRTC present?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3534</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Power Issues
threads.message: Thanks for your response. PPVRTC is present. I'll flow some flux under <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, but it looks perfect.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3534</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Power Issues
threads.message: I gave <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> the flux treatment. No cigar. Were you proposing replacing these chips?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3534</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Power Issues
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R8178</RESISTOR> is pretty unusual to be corroded. For liquid to get there it must also have affected the <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> area. Did you take pictures before cleaning? Can you post a good clear picture of the area?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3534</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Power Issues
threads.message:
No Title

Annoyingly I didn't take a photo of the <RESISTOR>R8178</RESISTOR> area before cleaning and repairing it. The resistor and one probe point were VERY corroded, the resistor literally fell right off. Really weird cause there is literally no sign of corrosion around <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>.

I did take a photo of the discoloured cap before i replaced that though. Attached is a couple photos of the board, the discoloured cap, and the <RESISTOR>R8178</RESISTOR> area post repair. The probe point next to it, connecting to <RESISTOR>R1667</RESISTOR> is almost completely gone from corrosion, but the little bit left is still making a solid connection to <RESISTOR>R4852</RESISTOR> for <SIGNAL>TPAD_SPI_MOSI</SIGNAL> and to <RESISTOR>R1667</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3534</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Power Issues
threads.message: If those pictures are of the current state <RESISTOR>R8178</RESISTOR> looks pretty sad, did you even replace that resistor. Have you checked continuity on both sides of the resistor to other components on those lines? Also I did not see a pic of <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> area.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3534</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Power Issues
threads.message: That's a replaced <RESISTOR>R8178</RESISTOR>, from a donor - it measures 100ohm as it should and has continuity on both sides. I don't think it is related to this problem, since <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> should be generated before reaching it and it isn't? The last photo shows <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> area on the left, but not through microscope - will take another photo in work today.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3534</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Power Issues
threads.message: Duke, you were, of course right. The left side of <RESISTOR>R8178</RESISTOR> had lost continuity, it DID have it, but it lost it, even though the pad underneath looked fine. I had to run a wire round to the other side of the board, connecting to the right side of <RESISTOR>R1462</RESISTOR>, which was actually measuring for <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>. Fan spinning now and problem solved! Thank you so much for your time.
